The guy who read the photo finish is purportedly the best in the business. There are two cameras, one filming from across the inside lane and one filming from across the outside lane. The outside image is the most frequently referred to in deciding races, but in this case, a raised arm obscured the torsos, making it impossible to determine which torso crossed the line first. It's the inside image that shows the torsos flush with the line. Although he first ruled Tarmoh third, he almost immediately second guessed himself and called in four referees for a consultation.

If Tarmoh believes she was rightly the winner, she was only so provisionally and only for the time it took the judge to overrule himself. I'm sensing that she's a vulnerable, inexperienced newcomer who has fallen back on her high school and college mentors because--as if things weren't complicated enough--she and Felix share a coach in Bobby Kersee who has been doing his best all week to avoid the conflict of interest of advising either runner what to do. When pressed, he said "It would be like your asking me which one of my kids I would let drown."

Neither Tarmoh, nor her chosen mentors, seem well enough versed in the "thrill of victory and the agony of defeat" nature of Olympic Trials competition. It's a tough game. Runners come flying to victory only to discover they are disqualified from stepping a half toe on the white line. To become a champion, you take the knocks, you rise, and you rise again.
Spot on! Another way would be to use their respective placements in the qualifying, quatrers and semis. Then the complaint might be, "but I wasn't really trying my hardest". Oh well.

A number of commenters are berating USATF for not having had a rule in place for such a situation. But considering that, with all the heats and semis and finals that have been run at Olympic Trials over the years, this has never happened before, I would cut them a little slack.

It's the three slots only that complicates the situation here; if they'd tied for first or second the third place finisher would have been out of luck. Presumably in open competition, they could have tied for the bronze, but the rules say only three can go to the Olympics. This situation was made so much more complicated by the fact that both girls had both entered in two events and both had been warming up, running, and cooling down all week. Ato Bolden for NBC was adamant that the issue should be settled by competitive means and not a coin toss, but that was easy for him to say, he was sitting in a booth on his fanny all week. A high stakes runoff? It's like asking them to just go out there and, why not?, tear a hamstring for TV.

Your suggestion that the tiebreaker should be the runners' progression of times has merit. During the rounds, advancing can depend either on placing or on the next fastest times, so the concept is already in place in track, it just needs to be formalized. Pole vaulters and high jumpers are placed based both on final height and progressive misses. No reason why qualifying times in the sprints can't be averaged in, but only to break a tie in a final at a trials.

After reading several reports, it seems that the official results declaring the race a tie for 3rd place were announced about two hours after the race, overturning the judge's initial "unofficial" declaration of Tarmoh as the 3rd place qualifier. If it took a panel of referees two hours to determine that this was a tie, then there need to be improvements made in the technology. It was another 24 hours before USATF proposed their coin flip or runoff alternatives to the two competitors.

Specific "tiebreaker" rules should be in place ahead of meets, instead of the ad hoc manner of this coin flip or runoff. For example, one could take combined times from all the qualifying heats leading up to the final...the runner with the lowest combined time wins. It would be rare indeed for the combined times from three or four races to be "equal" down to one-one thousandth of a second. The added benefit of that would be to make qualifying heats more competitive - running to advance would turn into running harder and faster to improve ones chances in a tiebreaker.

Once again, Mr. Brooks puts ideology before pragmatism by endorsing complex and inadequate 'market based' solutions when a simpler, more cost-effective health care reform alternative is available.

First, the Capretta and Moffitt plan endorsed by Mr. Brooks is just a fancy form of rationing. The wealthy would pay for more comprehensive 'defined contribution' medical plans, while the poor would be able to afford less. Unfortunately, though, health needs don't respect income levels. I might select the 'no frills' plan, but then might encounter a medical need that my plan doesn't address. What then? Additional defects in the Capretta/Moffitt plan include the likelihood that the proposed federal tax cut will be too small a subsidy to sufficiently offset rising medical costs, and the continuing use of premium revenues for the profit and administrative and marketing overhead of private insurers.

A better, simpler and more cost-effective approach would of course be a single-payer system, such as those provided in other advanced democracies. But sadly, Mr. Brooks's knee-jerk conservatism won't let him endorse this proven, cost-effective approach.

You state that Gina Ray's story is "not about innocence".  But if she is telling the truth that her ticket bore the wrong date, or really the right date but that her court date was moved to trick her into not being there, then her story is completely about innocence.  And many of these stories are about innocence.  A few months ago, I was pulled over in a commercial area "for speeding".  Before I slowed down, I looked at my speed and I was going 27 mph.  I asked how fast i was going, but the cop would not say.  He just said "over the speed limit", and wrote me up for "35+".  I went into court to fight the ticket, working on a case (I am an attorney) on the phone while waiting to go into court.  (How someone could fight a ticket who can't leave a job is beyond me.)  I told the judge the truth, hoping that she would believe me.  (I did not tell her I am a lawyer and officer of the court, as I did not believe that should make any difference over a non-lawyer.)  One of the two cops who pulled me over testified, lying on the stand that I was going over 35 mph.  The judge simply took the cop's word over mine, and I had to pay about $200 for not doing anything wrong.  Bringing private companies into the mix, whose incentive is to only make money, perverts justice and turns it into a travesty, destroying the lives of poor people!  We must end all victimless crimes, and free the 2 million in jail for them.  America was once the land of the free, now we are the land of the jailed.  No.
